intro: Trichophorum cespitosum nothosubsp. foersteri, commonly known as the Foerster's sedge, is a variant of the common sedge found in wetland environments. It is characterized by its grass-like appearance with narrow, linear leaves and produces small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in marshy areas and is adapted to moist, nutrient-rich soils. It plays a role in stabilizing wetland ecosystems and supporting local biodiversity. Its botanical classification highlights its close relationship to other sedges within the Cyperaceae family.
